bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Estela Agramonte Rodriguez Leon, October 16, 1940

div1.p: Hench sends Leon his speech for the Lazear memorial event at Washington and Jefferson College.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Estela Agramonte Rodriguez Leon, October 16, 1940
div1.opener:
(CARBON)
Wednesday
10/16/40
My dear Mrs Rodriguez - Leon
div1.p:
I am writing you in this unusual fashion in order
to save a little precious time and to have a memorandum of this
letter to you. Hence the pencil as I am using a carbon. I am
enclosing the last pages of my talk to be given at the
Washington & Jefferson affair just 10 days from now. The first
11 pages give a running account of the well-known story-
the formation of the Board, the work at Columbia Barracks & at
Las Animas Hospital, the death of Lazear (official version)
and then the work at Camp Lazear. To condense this into 11 pages
necessitated omitting much that I eventually will publish in
more ample form. But I was able to introduce all the characters
involved. Naturally in such a short account as this is
I have dealt, under the special circumstance, more with Lazear
than with any others and have therefore entitled this particular
paper “Dr Jesse W Lazear and his contribution to the Conquest
of Yellow Fever”. In order not to be misunderstood and to
be considered as favoring Lazear (and you are entirely right
when you say that a writer can, unless he is careful, be carried
away by one character) I have attached a footnote on the
front page as follows: on the occasion of the dedication of
a Lazear memorial the writer deems as appropriate to deal
chiefly with the activities of Lazear, but by so doing it is not
the writer's intention to minimize in the slightest degree
the contribution of any of the many persons who participated
in the conquest of this disease. The writer proposes to deal
elsewhere & more fully with the whole story"

I hasten to state that this note is NOT directed to
you but more to the admirers of C and to still those who
for example favor Kissinger over Moran etc etc,
I believe you have seen enough of me to know I have no
favorites and that I feel that the story is so wonderful that
it is my self-imposed & pleasant duty to re-assert
the glory of all - not excepting Finlay by any means

But the main purpose of my writing this hasty letter is to
beg of you to read over my interpretation of your remarks to
me as to your father's opinions re Lazear and to return
them at your very earliest convenience either with your
corrections or if it is alright, please just cable me the
following message COLLECT Hench - Rochester,
Minnesota - Approve. There are no other Henches here &
it will reach me promptly. The reason I want to hear from you
is that I dont want to quote you wrongly or attribute
to your father erroneous statements or even thoughts.
We will have plenty of time to change or correct it before it
is published in a medical journal but I have been
asked to have a copy ready for the Press as soon as
possible & would therefore like to hear from you before Sunday
or Monday if possible.

As you will see, I carefully omitted the several lines
to which you objected (lines written by me based apparently
on a faulty recollection of our conversation). I think I have
stuck to your actual words as much as possible but
in one or two sentences I paraphrased your remarks.
But I do so want to use it in quotation marks-
it makes the statements more authentic - it adds much
punch to them & not the least important it credits
the remarks properly - assigning their authorship to
you.

I am hastily doing the same thing with Gen.
Truby - getting him to confirm my quotations.
I see no conflict between your statements & his.
The only difference is that your father apparently speculated
a little more as to the possible motive of Lazear & I think
his speculations most interesting- I do hope I interpreted
them right,

I think your fathers tribute to Lazear was beautiful, so
lovely that I am using it as the closing quotation.

Furthermore it throws a splendid light on your fathers character-
I refer to his one simple statement of humility - a beautiful
attribute. I am sure the audience will be very thrilled to
hear this version & I am indeed grateful for permission to use
it.

Don't think that you have heard the last of me! No such
luck on your part. I have gotten this story into my blood
& have already collected so much data that I plan probably
to write a small (?) monograph on it & there I will need
all the help you can give, so that I can give due credit to all
concerned, fairly, critically but sympathetically. I will
write later about other details in your last letter, I shall
be most careful of the photo. It surely was taken at the
same hospital as the other - the roof construction in this
photo compares with that in the other. I believe it was
probably Las Animas but on having it copied & will
send copies to some survivors so that they can help
identify it - the place & people, I assume your father is the
figure on the right. The other vaguely resemble Lazear
but the beard looks too full.

Did you forget to tell me the relationship of your father
to the Agramonte on the postage stamps? Would you be
willing to let me photostat your fathers entire manuscript
instead of one page? I always like to return two for one
when possible & will if I can not only return the original
but also a photostat copy for you to keep so that other
pestiferous persons need not bother borrow your
prized original. How anxious I am to see more of
your fathers letters from Reed et al, his photographs,
& the drawings of Building #1 & 2. By the way
do you think the drawings were made in 1900 or
did he not make these notes writing his 1915 article?

I have written Mrs Lazear preparing her for this information but
Truby Kean (and I think army men whom they consulted) all agreed that
now was a most appropriate time to divulge this data.

I await your answer with eagerness but
some anxiety & do y hope you will approve.
